reviewText:
"Chi-raq" (2015 release; 118 min.) brings the story of gang violence in Chicago's south side. As the movie opens, we get Nick Cannon's "Pray 4 My City" playing on the screen, with nothing but the lyrics showing on the screen. After that, still more sobering info: stats showing the number of murders (7,356) in Chicago during 2001-2015 being higher than the number of casualties in the wars in Iraq and in Afghanistan. When we finally get to the story at hand, we get to know Chi-raq (played by Nick Gannon), a rapper and also part of one of the local gangs, and his girlfriend Lysistrata (played by Teyonah Parris). It's not before long that a young girl is killed by a stray bullet, leading from an outcry of the community. The woman decide to withhold sex from their men until an end to the street violence is reached. Will they succeed? To tell you more would spoil your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.

Couple of comments: this is the latest Spike Lee joint, and it is also the first movie in theaters from Amazon Studios (yes, THAT Amazon). The movie is said to be a modern day adaptation of the ancient Greek play "Lysistrata" by Aristophanes. How many of you have read or seen that play? I know I haven't, so I have no idea how closely the movie comes, in concept, spirit or otherwise, to the original Greek play. Much (but not all) of the movie's dialogue is indeed in verse, but it is done very loosely and if you didn't pay particular attention, you wouldn't even notice. The movie's lynch point is the funeral of the little girl, during which the minister (played by John Cusack) gives a thundering eulogy, condemning both the violence and the underlying societal problems (poverty, etc.). Samuel L. Jackson's character (Dolmedes) is the 'host' of the movie, providing biting commentary between scenes. Teyonah Parris, who broke through in last year's "Dear White People", plays a confident lead role and is the emotional centerpiece of the movie. Wesley Snipes, Angela Bassett and Jennifer Hudson all perform very nicely as well. But I have to say that Cusack's role as the white minister in an all-black church and community is the most shocking (if that is the right word) of all. The movie features plenty of great music, including performances from Nick Gannon, R. Kelly, Mail Music, and, surprisingly, Bruce Hornsby, among others. In all, I was pleasantly surprised with "Chi-raq", which is strong and cohesive, and easily Spike Lee's best work in YEARS (for my anyway).

The movie opened nationally this weekend. The Saturday matinee screening where I saw this at in a huge theater was attended dismally (I counted 5 people, including myself), much to my surprise and somewhat dismay. Sure, this isn't the easiest or most accessible movie, but the movie makes a lot of valid points, and is frankly a darn good movie. Maybe this will find a second life when streaming or eventually getting a DVD/Blu-ray release. Meanwhile, "Chi-raq" is definitely worth checking out!

I honestly didn't really know what to expect when I clicked "Watch Now", but I didn't anticipate the powerful and relatable story with a strong core message. The parallels between the Ancient Greek comedy play and the movie are loose but the original effort receives nods throughout. However, while CHI-RAQ has comedic elements, it is by no means a comedy. It undertakes an extremely serious subject of gang inner city violence and the rising rates of innocent bystander casualties that accompany said violence. Spike Lee lures you in with humor, grips you with good acting, and keeps you in with a message that is firmly rooted in a shocking reality.

Nick Cannon is a revelation as "Chi-Raq", the protagonist's love interest/adversary. Samuel L. Jackson is spot on with his running zingy commentary and a commanding yet nonchalant presence which has become kind of his trademark.  Angela Bassett is a spectacular powerhouse . The rest of the performances are noteworthy as well. And even though I am by no means a John Cusack fan, he delivers one of the most moving speeches of the movie.

All-in-all, this one is definitely well worth your time. This stylized entertaining drama will not start a riot, but it will sure make you think.

Combining music, dialog in rhyme, over-the-top characters acting more like characters from a medieval morality play than real persons, and some ham-fisted politicizing and polemics, Lee's work has to be taken for what it is or not at all, and demands more focused attention than most any film you might come across. The dialog is crammed with poetic flourishes, mostly in rhyme, and it's hard to say whether it's really "deep" or just portentous. It's an updating of Aristophanes' "Lysistrata" set in modern Southside Chicago (Chi-raq suggesting it's more like Iraq than a civilized city), so much pays homage to the Greek playwright's style. The plot? Upset about gun violence between rival gangs that causes the deaths of many innocents, the mistress of one gang leader follows the Greek method of getting the guys to give up the guns... "No peace, no pussy"... and convinces the other women to join the protest until the men surrender. Aristophanes was funnier.

As an adult, it reminds me of many great moderistic interpretations of Shakespeare, and I lament that there aren't more contemporary Classical adaptations out there. Call me lazy, but I not a Humanist...Just a Scientist who appreciates stylized traditional drama without paying theater prices. Was the satire logical or precise? No! But, it was beautifully and entertainingly executed. Nick  Cannon and Wesley Snipes impressed me so much that I needed IMDB to confirm who they were. Teyona Parrish always looks and acts differently in everything I've seen her in (which is kudos enough).

As far as Spike Lee fans go, I think people who lean heavily towards: She's Gotta Have It, School Daze, Girl 6, and maybe Son of Sam will appreciate it.

This movie blends well the Greek play Lysistrata with modern day problems of Black America.  This is much in response to several reviews I've seen.  I admit first that I am biased.  I love retelling of stories, I have a strong classical background and I am familiar with multiple of Spike Lee's Joints.  The verse was lovely the acting was superb. Use of song and dance breaks are common in Spike Lee movies so I was unsurprising.  I appreciated the fact that most of the elements that are causing strife in the Black Community: gun violence, police violence, the police to prison pipeline, lack of educational opportunity, Inaccessible health care, lack of jobs and economic opportunity as well as the government endorsement of these things. To those who say it is all over the place - truthfully these are just the things Black America deals with on a daily basis.  Not everything at once, but often parts each day. The church is a common place of meeting and interaction in the Black Community.  I did not see this as relying on god, but a way to mobilize a part of the community who still has a home base in the church.  I was astounded by John Cusack in this role which he played well. I appreciated the verse and the way it was intertwined with present day characters. There were many elements that held to the original story.  For me the  ending "competition" fell a little flat, but the original play just ended with a distracting woman named "reconciliation," who distracted the generals while they signed a peace treaty.  so I suppose I can forgive that.  I felt the two main characters were well flushed out and even some of the side characters were show to have some depth.  I feel this is definitely a worthwhile watch and may need a second watch to really get the details.

I thought it was different, creative and had an innovative way of showing how to get to the solution of less violence in Chicago. I really valued seeing that. Chiraq is a film that debuted on December 4th, 2015.  The film is directed by revered director Spike Lee, an outspoken film-maker who actively targets racial relations involving Black-Americans. Lees movie is focused on the overall destruction of Chicagos urban communities through gang violence by invoking the philosopher Aristophanes play Lysistrata.  Lysistrata is a comedy that tells a comic account of a womans extraordinary mission to end the Peloponnesian War by denying sexual advances from their lovers.  Spike Lee heavily borrows from this tale, even going so far as to name the main character of Chiraq Lysistrata.  Lee places heavy emphasis on one particular scene in which a seven-year-old child was killed by a stray bullet, leading to a community-led idea of promoting peace in these violence laden neighborhoods. While Chiraq delivers in recreating a modern Lysistrata, it fails to deliver a resounding message to empower the Black-American community.

 Chiraq at times, is an influential film, especially at moments where it reveals the disaster rampant gun violence has caused in Chicago alone. When Lee is able to make these points, the film becomes very inspirational as well as informative.  Specifically, when actor John Cusack (playing the role of a priest) delivers a moving message about the unavailability of resources lower income families face helps to convey the need for assistance for these communities.  By utilizing the reality that lower income families have lesser opportunities to succeed will no doubt open the eyes of people who deny this fact, or reassure the claims of the people who are looking to decrease the poverty gap.  However, while Spike Lee utilizes such methods to convey his message, these moments are not frequent enough to make the rest of the film meaningful.  Consequently, while I find Chiraq to have some interesting points to it, I feel that Lee loses the audience when he talks about womans empowerment and sexuality over gun violence and drugs.

 A short coming of the film is when Chiraq isn't talking about the plethora of gun violence in Chicago, it ends up talking about sex.  Thats right, a movie based on the terrors of south side Chicago, notorious for gang violence and drug trade, focuses on sex.  At one point in the film, main characters Chiraq and Lysistrata engage in a showdown, neither of words nor violence, but a sex showdown.  Spike Lee creates the notion that, if all women globally renounced sex and denied all men, world peace would follow.  At first I found this to be comical, like Aristophanes intended it to be, however I believe Spike Lee takes Aristophanes notion rather seriously and quite literally employs the usage of celibacy for peace.  In another instance, the women succeed in capturing a military armory by means of sensual seduction and when faced by the response of the police overtly chant, No Peace, No P***y.  Spike Lee began this film with statistics and realistic notions about how lower income families face a growing trend of rejection from politicians and lesser opportunities, and instead chose to implore all the women to promote sexual celibacy to cause their men to have a cathartic reaction and abstain from violence.  Although these parts are often hilarious, I often found myself questioning the seriousness of these scenes and repeatedly I was left bewildered if this movie was looking to be informative or a dramatic comedy.

Chiraq expects audiences to be well-versed in the humanities, while also forcing the audience to take Lees views on current events as facts, truth be damned.  However, there are simply too many instances where Lees emphasis on the comical points of Lysistratas denial of sex as a focal point for the film.  At one point in the film where the characters are discussing how they are going to go about denying their significant other access to their bodies, one character announces, Well, what about the thots?  And I too announced, yes, what about the thots?  Initially Lysistrata states that shell go ahead and recruit them as well, but in reality there is no such culpability. Regardless of what your goal is or how persuasive you may be, there will always someone who does not care about your ideals, no matter how righteous you are. I give Spike Lee credit for attempting to make the film Chiraq an eye opener, however I feel that he has missed a great opportunity to bring to light the poverty lower income families, especially Black-Americans, face and the racial tension that heavily influences this detriment. If Spike Lees goal was to make a modernization of Aristophanes Lysistrata the dramatic comedy, he has done justice, if he meant it to be a serious critique of the City of Chicago and revealing means of ending gun crime, he may need to reconsider his profession.

 According to critic Richard Roeper of the Chicago Sun Times, Chiraq isn't a broad comedy nor a gratuitous slam at our city of Chicago, and instead is a thunderous wake-up alarm to resolve our gang violence and save our city. While I agree that Spike Lees film has delivered a powerful message and has utilized parts of his film to instill a sense of community, he has failed to deliver the means to follow through.  In another point of his review, Roeper states how the global-wide sex strike is ludicrous, but the reality of young men shooting one another over gang colors and turf wars as equally ridiculous.  While this statement is true, I do not agree that this justifies Spike Lees inclusion of this ridiculous idea that a sex strike would lead to peace.  If Spike Lees goal of this movie was to get the topic started on gang violence, in the first thirty minutes of the movie he has succeeded, however it quickly divulged into a topic of why is there so much sex? became paramount throughout the rest.

 Conclusively, I can only recommend this film to people who are well versed in the humanities and can understand the several niche references Spike Lee creates in order to fully grasp the concept of Chiraq. I would also recommend that if anyone who intends on watching Chiraq to also review the play Lysistrata by Aristophanes, and several older Greek mythologies such as Oedipus, as Chiraq is a direct modernization of this play.  Anyone who has a lesser knowledge of Greek mythologies and plays, will question why Samuel L. Jackson is dressed in a pimp suit and often yells at the audience, or why the women constantly yell No Peace, No P***y, and undoubtedly question Spike Lees touch on film-making.

This movie is art at its finest. Make no mistake--it deserves its R-rating, for both violence, language and sexual content. But brilliantly, Spike Lee uses the Ancient Green story of Lysistrata, who famously stopped a war by getting all the wives in the city to go on strike from their marriage beds, not only as the story, but also in the form of the performance. With an orator framing the action, and all the dialog (more or less) in rhyme, there is just enough emotional distance to make the brutality of the subject matter bearable, leaving me uplifted rather than traumatized. With plenty of singing, dancing, and eye candy, Lee uses the cultural modes and idiom of those he is speaking to and about to tell the human story behind the glorification of gang violence as well as the violence of racism and warfare--connections few are making in simplistic arguments either for or against gun control. He even gets in a few statistics, too, in entertaining ways, as well as the larger cultural context of the U.S. in perpetual wars, prison for profit, and the grinding poverty our economy enforces. This is the kind of movie than can, sometimes, create lasting change. Here's hoping.
